context_text:
different (adj): not the same 
 Used with verbs: 
Our friendship is different now.
(be: is/am/are, feels, seems, appears))

Her voice sounds different.
(sounds)

The apples taste different.
(taste, look)
 Used with adverbs: 
The two brothers are very different.
(very, far, clearly, significantly, completely, entirely, quite, totally)

Our views are rather different.
(rather, somewhat, slightly, subtly)
 Used with prepositions: 
Animals are different from humans.
(from, than)
 Used with nouns: 
Those clothes are from a different age.
(age, country, era, fashion, time, generation)

He follows a different method.
(method, path, strategy)

Look at the situation from a different outlook.
(outlook, perspective, point of view, standpoint, viewpoint)

used (adj): was owned or handled before 
 Used with adverbs: 
That is a commonly used phrase.
(commonly, frequently, widely, regularly))

Our rarely used piano is being sold.
(rarely)

We are donating lightly used clothes.
(lightly)
 Used with verbs: 
The couch is used, but we'll take it anyway.
(be: is/am/are, looks)
 Used with nouns: 
Used books are cheaper than new ones.
(books)

He works at a used car dealership.
(car)

The charity takes used clothing.
(clothing)

important (adj): significant and valuable 
 Used with verbs: 
The message seems important.
(seems, sounds, be: is/am/are))

She makes me feel important.
(feel)

What makes you so important?
(makes)

He believes he is very important.
(believes, thinks)

His findings have become important to the research.
(become, remained)
 Used with adverbs: 
It is extremely important that you see a doctor.
(extremely, very, critically)

Good communication is tremendously important in a marriage.
(tremendously, vitally, particularly, especially, incredibly)

Both suggestions are equally important.
(equally, obviously, very, profoundly)

It is pretty important that you finish the project on time.
(pretty, fairly, quite, obviously)
 Used with prepositions: 
It's important for you to read this.
(for)

Spending time with my family is important to me.
(to)
 Used with nouns: 
There will be an important addition to the company.
(addition, change)

She missed a very important appointment.
(appointment, assignment, clue, detail, fact, feature, ingredient, item, meeting, part, piece, requirement)

They made an important breakthrough.
(breakthrough, discovery, finding)

He is an important client.
(client, customer, guest, person, visitor)

I had to make an important decision.
(decision)

She learned an important lesson.
(lesson)

That was an important moment for him.
(moment, occasion, place, reminder, role, victory)

every (adj): all; each 
 Used with nouns: 
I have heard every excuse possible for being late.
(excuse, justification))

He is late every time.
(time, day, week)

She likes every kind of ice cream.
(kind, type, flavor)

This plan has every chance of working.
(chance)

We have taken every step necessary.
(step)

She makes the most of every opportunity she gets.
(opportunity, chance)

large (adj): big in size or amount 
 Used with verbs: 
He is a large man.
(be: is/am/are))

The house looks very large.
(looks, appears, seems, feels)

His debt remained quite large.
(remained)

The plant grew very large.
(grew, got, became)
 Used with adverbs: 
The jacket looked very large on her.
(very, extremely, fairly, quite, too)

Their house was exceptionally large.
(exceptionally, incredibly, relatively, overly, surprisingly, unusually, ridiculously)

I wonder if this room will be large enough for our furniture.
(enough)
 Used with nouns: 
She has a very large house.
(house, apartment, closet, car, garden, backyard)
 *many additional nouns

available (adj): ready to be used or purchased; able to talk or meet someone 
 Used with verbs: 
That apartment is available.
(be: is/am/are, became))
 Used with adverbs: 
Water is easily available.
(easily, freely, readily)

When did that book become commercially available?
(commercially, publicly, locally, widely)

Parking spaces are usually available.
(usually, generally, commonly, often, never, rarely)

I do not have that much money instantly available.
(instantly, immediately)

The doctor is currently available to see you.
(currently, now)
 Used with prepositions: 
Tickets are available for purchase.
(for)

School counseling is available to anyone who needs it.
(to)

Extra textbooks are available from the teachers.
(from)

popular (adj): liked by many people 
 Used with nouns: 
She won the popular vote.
(vote, election))

Everyone wants to be the popular kid in school.
(kid, guy, girl, boy)

This park is a popular destination.
(destination, place, spot, attraction)

That is a popular saying.
(saying, quote)

She wears popular brands.
(brands)
 Used with adverbs: 
He is the most popular kid in his class.
(most, least)

That show is very popular.
(very, extremely, fairly, highly, incredibly)

She is becoming increasingly popular.
(increasingly, equally, widely)

He became instantly popular.
(instantly)
 Used with verbs: 
She is popular at school.
(be: is/am/are, seems)

He became popular after the football game.
(became, got, grew)

The show remained popular for many years.
(remained, stayed)
 Used with prepositions: 
This music is popular with the kids.
(with, among)

That show is popular in Europe.
(in)

able (adj): capable of doing something; good at doing something 
 Used with verbs: 
I am able to go with you.

He is able to come with me.

They are able to go together.
(be: is/am/are))

He seems able to do the work.
(seems, feels)
 Used with adverbs: 
I am quite able to walk home alone.
(quite, perfectly)

They are not financially able to buy a house yet.
(financially)

The child is not mentally able to do something so difficult.
(mentally, physically)

I was barely able to see the small letters.
(barely, hardly)

If you get proper training, you will be better able to do the task.
(better, more)

basic (adj): necessary; easiest; important without any extras 
 Used with nouns: 
Does he know the basic colors of the rainbow?
(colors))

She does not have basic skills for the job.
(skills, knowledge, qualifications)

He understands the basic idea of the plan.
(idea, principle)

Typing is a basic requirement for the job.
(requirement, need)

Candidates have to go through basic training to move to the next level.
(training)

We need basic supplies to do the job.
(supplies, tools, materials)

known (adj): familiar, accepted as knowledge by many people 
 Used with nouns: 
There is no known cure for the disease.
(cure, cause))

He is a known criminal.
(criminal, terrorist)

It is a known fact that excessive eating causes weight gain.
(fact)

There are no known side effects with this medication.
(side effects)

various (adj): different 
 Used with verbs: 
Shoes come in various colors.
(come))

He has lived in various places in the world.
(lived, resided, dwelled)

He watches various programs on television.
(watches, sees, views)
 Used with nouns: 
People come from various backgrounds.
(backgrounds, nationalities)

There are various forms of plant life.
(forms, kinds, types)

They came for various reasons.
(reasons, occasions)

difficult (adj): hard, challenging 
 Used with verbs: 
The situation is difficult.
(be: is/am/are, looks, proves, remains, seems, sounds, looks))

A job can become difficult.
(become, get)

The noise made studying difficult.
(made)

I found the math difficult.
(found)
 Used with adverbs: 
Her homework was extremely difficult.
(extremely, very, incredibly, particularly, really)

The problem was fairly difficult.
(fairly, a little, slightly)
 Used with nouns: 
I took on a difficult assignment.
(assignment, challenge, job, task)

That was a difficult exam.
(exam, climb, hurdle, issue, journey, problem, question, topic, undertaking)

She had a difficult birth.
(birth, childhood, condition, decision, pregnancy)

He is in a difficult position.
(position, situation, relationship)

several (pro): more than two of something; a few people or things 
 Example sentences: 
Several of us are going to the movies.

Several of the visitors brought flowers.

Several of the guests left early.

Several of the family members got into an argument.

Several of the students stayed after school to finish the project.

Several of the teachers had a meeting after school.

Several of the employees were fired for stealing.
)

united (adj): joined together 
 Used with adverbs: 
They are firmly united to fight the problem.
(firmly, strongly, tightly, absolutely))

The family members were totally united to keep things peaceful.
(totally, fully)

They have stayed legally united throughout this whole ordeal.
(legally, politically)
 Used with verbs: 
Our country stands united after the attack.
(stands, has become, remains, be: is/am/are)
 Used with prepositions: 
They stand united against drunk driving.
(against)

They stayed united with each other.
(with)

They stand united in their decision.
(in)

historical (adj): concerning past events 
 Used with nouns: 
There are many historical accounts of that event.
(accounts))

We're going through the historical archives.
(archives, documents, collection, photographs, materials)

They are concerned with historical accuracy.
(accuracy, inaccuracy)

They met with representatives from the historical association.
(association, museum, society)

She likes to read historical fiction.
(fiction, novels, stories)

That event has great historical importance.
(importance, significance)

They are looking at the historical framework of the law.
(framework, record, evolution)

What is the historical basis for his claim?
(basis, background, context, standpoint)

They are investigating from a historical perspective.
(perspective, point of view, interpretation)

There is little historical understanding of that event.
(understanding, knowledge)

He is an important historical figure.
(figure, person)

They will visit many historical monuments on their trip.
(monuments, sites)

They are looking at the historical data.
(data, examples, explanations, details, parallels)

hot (adj): having a high temperature; not cold; spicy 
 Used with verbs: 
The weather is so hot.
(be: is/am/are))

The day suddenly became hot.
(became, grew, turned, got)

She feels hot sitting by the fire.
(feels, looks, be: is/am/are)

I hope the food stays hot.
(stays)

This should be eaten hot.
(eaten, served)

The container should keep the food hot.
(keep)

This tastes too hot.
(tastes, be: is/am/are)
 Used with adverbs: 
It's extremely hot.
(extremely, fairly, very, quite, too)

Summers are really hot here.
(really, incredibly, scorching, unbearably, uncomfortably)

It's a little hot today.
(a little)

The soup was scalding hot.
(scalding, piping, steaming, burning, boiling)

Is that hot enough?
(enough)

Her food is extremely hot.
(extremely, really, pretty)

The coffee is slightly hot.
(slightly, a little)
 Used with nouns: 
This is a really hot day.
(day, afternoon, month, summer)

Would you like some hot coffee?
(coffee, tea, chocolate, cider)

She felt a blast of hot air when she opened the door.
(air)

Make sure the oven is hot.
(oven, stove, burner, broiler, grill)

They live in a hot climate.
(climate, country)

She made him a hot meal.
(meal, breakfast, lunch, dinner, supper)

I can't eat this hot pepper.
(pepper, curry, mustard)

I'm going to take a hot shower.
(shower, bath)

Be careful with the hot coals.
(coals)

The hot sand hurt her feet.
(sand)

They relaxed in the hot tub.
(tub, springs)

useful (adj): helpful 
 Used with adverbs: 
This information is very useful.
(very, extremely, fairly, highly, especially, incredibly, particularly))

Her cooking skills have been truly useful.
(truly, really, certainly)
 Used with verbs: 
Make yourself useful and help me with this.
(make)

She has become one of the most useful members on the team.
(become)

This information is very useful.
(be: is/am/are, looks, seems)

You might find this useful.
(find, consider)
 Used with nouns: 
I need some useful advice.
(advice, suggestions)

Thanks for the useful information.
(information, contribution, feedback)
 Used with prepositions: 
That information was very useful to the tourists.
(to)

That book is useful for beginners.
(for)

Computers are very useful in classrooms.
(in)

mental (adj): having to do with the mind 
 Used with nouns: 
Can you form a mental picture?
(picture, image))

It requires mental exertion.
(exertion, effort, strength, discipline)

She has poor mental fitness.
(fitness, activity, energy, stability)

Her mental agility is failing.
(agility, capability, ability, health)

He suffers from mental problems.
(problem, instability, retardation, lapses, exhaustion, fatigue, distress)

He has a good mental attitude.
(attitude)

He was sent to a mental asylum.
(asylum, institution, hospital)

She is experiencing great mental anguish.
(anguish, stress, strain, suffering, torture)

He had a mental breakdown.
(breakdown)

He has a mental disease.
(disease, disorder, illness, imbalance, disability, handicap)

He does mental arithmetic to work his brain.
(arithmetic, calculations, exercises)

She is a mental patient.
(patient)

What is her mental condition?
(condition, state)

scared (adj): afraid 
 Used with verbs: 
She looked scared during the movie.
(looked, got, grew, became, appeared, felt, seemed, be: was/were))
 Used with adverbs: 
The boy is extremely scared of the dark.
(extremely, very, a little, terribly, awfully)
 Used with prepositions: 
Are you scared of the dark?
(of)

He was scared at the thought of leaving his parents for the weekend.
(at)

She is scared about a lot of things.
(about, of)

additional (adj): more of something 
 Used with nouns: 
There is an additional charge to rent a larger hotel room.
(charge, fee, cost, expense))

There were additional complications after the surgery.
(complications)

We need an additional copy for our records.
(copy)

The car has additional features.
(features)

The students need additional help after school.
(help, assistance, guidance)

Do you need additional information?
(information)

There is additional storage in the garage.
(storage, space)

emotional (adj): related to strong feelings 
 Used with verbs: 
She was emotional after watching the movie.
(be: was/were, felt, looked, seemed))

He became very emotional during the funeral.
(became, got, grew)

Sad movies make her emotional.
(make)
 Used with adverbs: 
She felt extremely emotional after her dog died.
(extremely, fairly, very)

He gets overly emotional during football games.
(overly, too)

A wedding can be a highly emotional event.
(highly, deeply, intensely)
 Used with prepositions: 
She becomes emotional about many things.
(about, toward)
 Used with nouns: 
She felt an emotional connection immediately.
(connection)

His emotional response was unexpected.
(response, reaction)

The president gave an emotional speech during the crisis.
(speech, address)

This actress has good emotional depth.
(depth, expression)

The movie ended with an emotional scene.
(scene, tribute, farewell, reunion, climax)

old (adj): not young; having lived a long time; not new; of a certain age 
 Used with verbs: 
She seems very old for her age.
(seems, looks, feels, be: is/am/are))

She's getting wiser as she grows older.
(grows, gets, becomes)
 
This jacket is really old.
(be: is/am/are)
 Used with nouns: 
I saw an old girlfriend today.
(girlfriend, boyfriend, friend, acquaintance)

That is old news to us.
(news)

We should respect old people.
(people, legends, folks)

That is the old way of doing things.
(way)

They lived to a very old age.
(age)

An old lady lives next door.
(lady, woman, person, man, couple)

We saw an old movie.
(movie)

This song is an old favorite.
(favorite)

They came from the old country.
(country, world)

I told her an old story.
(story)

We are trying to get rid of old clothes.
(clothes, habits)

They live in an old building.
(building, home, house)

I know many old songs.
(songs, stories, jokes, customs)
 
Have a look at these old photographs.
(photographs)

Her clothes are of old fashion.
(fashion, style)
 Used with adverbs: 
He is too old to be playing on the swings.
(too)

She is old enough to drive.
(enough)

They are tearing down a very old house.
(very, extremely, fairly)

political (adj): related to politics; related to the government 
 Used with nouns: 
He is a political candidate.
(candidate, prisoner))

Do you belong to a political party?
(party)

What are your political ties?
(ties, views, opinions)

I don't care about political issues.
(issues, power, awareness)

She studied political science.
(science, economics, movements)

Her political career is not going well.
(career, campaign)

They are having a political discussion.
(discussion, debate)
 Used with verbs: 
She is getting too political for my taste.
(be + getting, be + becoming)

My father is very political.
(be: is/am/are)
 Used with adverbs: 
The discussion is getting very political.
(very, highly, too)

It was a purely political move.
(purely)

similar (adj): being almost the same 
 Used with verbs: 
That apple is similar to the one I ate yesterday.
(be: is/am/are, looks, tastes))

The trumpet sounds similar to the trombone.
(sounds, seems, appears)

They remain similar in color.
(remain)

The couple became similar in personality.
(became)
 Used with adverbs: 
These two songs are extremely similar.
(extremely, very, awfully, fairly, somewhat)

The twins are remarkably similar in personality.
(remarkably, strikingly, surprisingly, quite)

The teachers share roughly similar lesson plans.
(roughly, basically, essentially, fundamentally)
 Used with prepositions: 
The two rooms are similar in size.
(in)

He acts similar to his older brother.
(to)
 Used with nouns: 
I noticed a similar pattern.
(pattern, scenario)

The sisters have similar fashion.
(fashions, personalities, backgrounds, sizes)

healthy (adj): not sick or ill; good for your body; working well 
 Used with verbs: 
He appears healthy.
(appears, feels, looks, seems, be: is))

She is becoming healthy.
(be + becoming, be + getting)

He is trying to stay healthy.
(stay, keep, remain)

Changes to her diet are making her healthy.
(be + making, be + keeping)
 Used with adverbs: 
He has always been extremely healthy.
(extremely, very, fairly, quite, rather)

The doctor said she is perfectly healthy.
(perfectly, completely, generally)

His diet is reasonably healthy.
(reasonably, relatively)

She was tired but otherwise healthy.
(otherwise)

He tries to stay mentally healthy.
(mentally, physically)

The company is financially healthy.
(financially)
 Used with nouns: 
We are looking for healthy options.
(options, alternatives, substitutes, snacks, recipes)

He has a healthy appetite.
(appetite, attitude, lifestyle)

She just hopes for a healthy baby.
(baby, infant, child)

They ate a healthy breakfast.
(breakfast, meal, lunch, dinner)

She tries to keep a healthy diet.
(diet)

We are experiencing healthy growth.
(growth, sales, profits, returns)

They have a healthy relationship.
(relationship)

This is not a healthy situation.
(situation)

The economy is healthy right now.
(economy)

There should be a healthy balance between work and free time.
(balance)

financial (adj): relating to finance or money 
 Used with nouns: 
He provided free financial advice to those in need.
(advice))

The financial market is on edge today.
(market, industry, company)

They are calling for financial reform.
(reform, regulation, reorganization, sanctions)

She is trying to increase her financial independence.
(independence, security, well-being, stability)

He was accused of financial misconduct.
(misconduct, fraud, corruption)

They are reviewing his financial records.
(records, plan, plan, strategy, statements)

They are providing financial assistance to those affected by the disaster.
(assistance, help, aid)

His financial success is impressive.
(success, knowledge, return)

We are close to a financial disaster.
(disaster, collapse)

They released the financial projections for the industry.
(projections, numbers, data, information)

Those with financial need will receive scholarships.
(need)

The financial consequence will be big.
(consequence, risk, reward)

She is a financial burden.
(burden, liability)

He is a financial specialist.
(specialist, advisor, journalist, editor, writer, reporter)

He has a lot of financial obligations.
(obligations, responsibilities)

medical (adj): relating to medicine 
 Used with nouns: 
He went to medical school.
(school))

She is a medical doctor.
(doctor, expert, professional, technician, scientist, specialist, director)

She needs medical treatment.
(treatment, supervision, intervention, coverage, attention, care, help, training)

We asked for medical advice.
(advice, assistance, aid, insurance, expertise)

The medical procedure took three hours.
(procedure, examination, consultation)

There has been a medical breakthrough.
(breakthrough, discovery)

He is having medical problems.
(problems)

The medical establishment does not agree with the recent findings.
(establishment, literature, community)

We have a medical appointment tomorrow.
(appointment)

Our medical costs are too high.
(costs, expenses, expenditures)

Can I see his medical chart?
(chart, file, report, records, history)

He studies medical science.
(science)

Medical terminology is sometimes confusing.
(terminology)

What's his medical condition?
(condition, diagnosis)

I entered the medical facility.
(facility, field, profession, team)

There was a medical emergency.
(emergency, experiment, error)

She's on medical leave.
(leave)

Do you know this medical term?
(term)

traditional (adj): being part of a custom or belief that is handed down through time 
 Used with adverbs: 
She comes from a very traditional family.
(very, extremely, fairly))
 Used with verbs: 
He has become very traditional since getting married.
(become)

She is very traditional.
(be: is/am/are)
 Used with nouns: 
She wants a traditional wedding.
(wedding, wedding dress, education, family)

He is bringing some traditional dishes to the potluck.
(dishes, food)

The students will be displaying traditional clothing to the audience.
(clothing, costumes)

There is a traditional saying.
(saying)
 
We are using a traditional approach.
(approach, concept, method, technique)

federal (adj): relating to a form of government where individual states share control with central or national government 
 Used with nouns: 
The federal government declared a state of emergency after the earthquake.
(government))

He works for a federal agency.
(agency, bureau, department, commission, institute)

We need to research the federal policy on immigration.
(policy, requirements, regulations, guidelines)

Their program receives a lot of federal funding.
(funding, assistance, grants, revenue, subsidies, money)

Federal prisoners are being transported to another location.
(prisoners, inmates)

They voted in the recent federal election.
(election)

The data from the federal census should be available soon.
(census, investigation)
 
There was a federal restriction on travel to Cuba.
(restriction, crackdown)

Security is tight in federal buildings.
(buildings, facilities, offices)

We are waiting on federal approval.
(approval)

A federal inspector will be here today.
(inspector, agent, judge, worker, official)

He is accused of a federal offense.
(offense, felony)

Many federal highways are in need of repairs.
(highways)

There is a federal holiday on Monday.
(holiday)

He went to jail for not paying federal taxes.
(taxes)

He was arrested for trespassing on federal land.
(land, property)

entire (adj): all of something 
 Used with nouns: 
She spent the entire evening doing homework.
(evening, day, afternoon, morning, night))

Their entire family is meeting at the beach.
(family, class, group)

The entire neighborhood attended the town meeting.
(neighborhood)

They spent their entire budget on food.
(budget, money)

The entire document needs changing.
(document, concept, story)

She didn't miss class the entire semester.
(semester, month, year, term)

She has been blind her entire life.
(life)

The entire building had to be evacuated.
(building, region, area, city)

strong (adj): having great physical or mental strength; having a sharp taste or odor 
 Used with verbs: 
She felt strong after the surgery.
(felt, be: was/were, looked, became, got, grew))

Our team finished strong.
(finished, remained, stayed, stood)

Garlic and onions smell strong.
(smell, taste)

All the weight lifting has made him very strong.
(made, kept)
 Used with adverbs: 
She is extremely strong.
(extremely, very, exceptionally, incredibly, surprisingly)

I don't think you're strong enough to lift the table.
(enough)

He is not very physically strong.
(physically, emotionally, mentally)
 Used with nouns: 
He was showing off his strong muscles.
(muscles, arms, legs)

The drink has a strong smell.
(smell, odor, flavor, taste)

I have a strong affection for her.
(affection, love, feeling, dislike, hatred)

There is strong proof that he is innocent.
(proof, evidence)

There are strong criticisms of his teaching style.
(criticisms, opinions)

There was strong opposition to the war.
(opposition, resistance)

actual (adj): real or true 
 Used with nouns: 
Scientists have been trying to prove the actual existence of aliens for many years.
(existence))

The actual number of people who got injured in the fire is much higher.
(number)

The actual size of the product is much smaller.
(size)

The actual cost for repairs is higher than the estimate.
(cost, amount)

I smiled at them, but my actual thought was not nice.
(thought, feeling)

Animals have actual feelings.
(feelings, emotions)

People finally got to see his actual personality.
(personality, behavior)

This is the actual place where the movie was filmed.
(place, street, location, site)

significant (adj): very important; having special meaning 
 Used with verbs: 
His actions were significant.
(be: was/were, proved))

He became significant to the story.
(became, remained)

The actions were considered significant to their rescue.
(be + considered, be + deemed, be + regarded as, be + seen as, be + viewed as)
 Used with adverbs: 
This house is very significant to our family.
(very, extremely, especially, fairly)

Martin Luther King Jr. was a particularly significant figure in the Civil Rights era.
(particularly, especially, deeply, highly)

The findings were historically significant.
(historically, culturally, biologically, politically, religiously, scientifically)
 Used with prepositions: 
Her actions proved significant for those around her.
(for, to)

successful (adj): achieving an aim or purpose 
 Used with verbs: 
He is very successful in the business world.
(be: is/am/are, seems, appears))

She became successful at a young age.
(became)

I feel successful in this sports car.
(feel)
 Used with adverbs: 
The event was surprisingly successful.
(surprisingly, tremendously, incredibly, extremely, fairly, very, enormously, hugely, truly, remarkably)

Our projects have not been entirely successful.
(entirely, completely, totally, consistently, reasonably)

His plan was only partially successful.
(partially, partly, relatively, marginally, moderately)
 Used with prepositions: 
He has been incredibly successful at building his career.
(at)

He has been very successful with his investments.
(with)

electrical (adj): related to a form of energy supplied through wires to operate machines or things run on power 
 Used with nouns: 
We must replace the old electrical system.
(system))

That electrical cord is broken.
(cord, circuit, socket, wire)

He fixed the cord with electrical tape.
(tape)

I need to plug in this electrical device.
(device, appliance, equipment)

He studied electrical engineering.
(engineering, repair)

expensive (adj): costing a lot of money; not cheap
